The pizza wasn't remarkable, but it tasted fresh and the ambiance was pleasant. They don't appear to make my favorite pizza (margharita with tomatoes and fresh basil) - oh well. It was convenient, inexpensive, and quick.

Sicilian deep-dish pizza is available by the slice.
author: Jennifer L.

description: Delicious pizza. The crust was really good and you can call them to have it delivered. Our piazza was veggie with basil, mushrooms, olives, green peppers, and cheese. We almost ate it all because it was so good! We got the smaller of the two sizes offered.
author: Martha N.

description: Great NY style pizza that you can customize by the slice. Would definitely come back. :) I didn't catch the owner's name, but he was really nice and so was the service. He has these cute photos on the wall to remind him of NY.
author: Jenny W.

description:
FOOD:
1.) Pepperoni pizza = pretty good


SERVICE:
Nice friendly service. They gave a cardboard box even tho it was just a slice.


ATMOSPHERE:
Cute small place, with outdoor seating as well

7.9
author: Angela L.

description: Good pizza. Try the meatball sandwich too.
author: Shane N.

description:
Pizza bagel.

Confident they'd say no when asking if I could get an egg white and marina sauce bagel for breakfast.

Confident saying they're awesome for doing it and doing it well. Delicious.

WiFi available while you sip caffeinated drinks like a large and inexpensive americano.

Makes up for the so so first experience. This one was just so so good.
author: Jason B.

description:
I really wanted to like this place, since it;s small, sincere, and informal.  But, no salad available.  The xlarge pizza is just enough for three people (we had four), so we ordered a couple pieces of sicilian (more like a focaccio, if you as me). 
The whole pie was thin and crispy, just right in my view, but the sauce, cheese and toppings were just ok.  We had the lombard, and it didn't seem really memorable, even with anchovies.  

I'd come back for happy hour, where there is cheaper cheese pizza and beer.... but for the price, it's a little high for what you get
author: Gary Y.

description:
My friend and I got some pepperoni slices to go from this place yesterday. The service was fast and friendly and since we got the pizza to-go we were given a decent size pizza box (rather than the small to go packages you sometimes get at other pizza places). They were sold out of some of their pizza options when I first arrived but I guess they were in the process of making more and this meant a 30 minute wait for their prosciutto and sausage options.

The pizza was good but a little on the greasy side. I found myself leaning a lot to avoid the greasy dripping on my clothes. All in all I'll be back here when I'm craving some pizza and want a nearby option. To be fair I need to try one of their freshly made pizza options and eat it in the restaurant rather than getting it to go.
author: Bryan B.

description:
I don't write a review, whether good or bad, very often and only do so when I feel it is warranted and I have actually something to say about certain stores, restaurants or repair shops and their service, food or quality of workmanship, for example, and not just for the sake of 'yelping' or blabbing about something that has nothing or very little to do with the place that's being reviewed. However, today is one of those days where I feel a review is in order. 

Had to take my mother to the doc's office this morning and afterwards we stopped at Avellino for a couple of slices. She's a pizza connoisseur and definitely knows a great NY-style pie when she sees it. Anyway, she had the veggie slice of the day, a mushroom/red onion and I had a plain cheese and a sausage slice. 

I have had my fair share of NY-style pizza here in the City and Avellino is hands down the best in SF. The crust was light, airy and had a nice crunch to it without being chewy. The slices were foldable and the tip had a flop to it that NYC slices are known for, which leads me to believe that the dough might have a bit of oil in it. The flavor of the crust was balanced, with a slight hint of salt. My guess is that it is a low-hydration dough, maybe around 59%-60% with no sugar. Well, at least I wasn't able to detect any sweetness in the crust whatsoever. I think it's just flour, water, salt, yeast and a touch of oil, maybe around 1% or so. And since they use whole milk mozzarella from Wisconsin, my bet is that it comes from the Grande Cheese Company.

The cheese/sauce ratio was perfectly balanced, with the sauce having a slightly sweet undertone, and the sausage had a nice fennel flavor without the fennel being overpowering. My mother was blown away. She just loved every bite of the slice and kept mumbling about what a perfect crust it is.

I've been to Avellino three times now and they never disappoint. Much better than over-hyped and over-priced Amici's, Tony's or Arinell's. Service is always friendly and accommodating. The only other place that rivals Avellino is Marcello's on Castro Street.

Avellino is always great and I'll be back for more when the pizza craving comes back in the future. Everything in moderation, though.
author: Mike K.

description:
A nice cosy place. The pizza was nice and yummy . New york style the kind I like.  I think it was a min of 10 bux for credit cards.

Overall , love the pizzas. Will come here again.
author: Archie R.

description: The pizza is delicious.  I just get annoyed because sometimes they accidentally leave their phone off the hook.  ANNOYING.  I want to order and pick up so I don't have to wait with my kids and the phone is off the hook.  I could not get through on Halloween and can't get through tonight.  LOVE THE PIZZA.  Just wish they'd pick up the phone!!!
author: Nettie A.

description:
If this place wasn't so far out of the way, it would be a lot more popular.  Solid pizza, NYC-style.  Do not come here if you're looking for healthy options.  Unlike most sf pizza joints, Avellino has cheese pizza at the ready, then they throw toppings on after you order.  

Try their breakfast pizzas on the weekends!  They also have bottomless mimosas for only $5!  There's also a TV inside showing sports most times.
author: Derek L.

description: Crust is a little burnt and its a little too oily but my dad and I enjoy coming here for lunch every so often when we're in the area
author: Rodney S.

description: The staff is very friendly. For $3.50/ slice I'm not complaining at all! Very large portions. I would recommend this place for a quick bite to eat.
author: Sarah L.

description:
I've read that this place took on a former employee of Arinell Pizza in the Mission- that'd explain a lot, as the pizza here is very similar to what you'd find at Arinell. That is a good thing. Legit NY pizza with traditional toppings (no West Coast bastardizations like Pineapple, as far as I could tell.) 

Located across the street from the Lombard entrance to the Presidio.
author: Joe M.

description:
I call Pizzeria Avellino all the time for delivery and It's always fast and fresh. The pies are really good too, maybe a little higher priced than I'd like to pay, but no where near the grilling I get if I go to some other joints. 

It's a staple in my local delivery diet.
author: Michael S.

description:
My husband is from NY and he is pretty picky when it comes to pizza but he liked this place too!

They sell pizza by the slice too but we ordered a medium pie with just pepperonis. It took about 25 min for them to bake but it came out piping hot and the pizza was delicious, just like the ones you can pick up in one of those good&quick pizza places in NYC.

Things we didn't like about this place were the size of the restaurant (Super tiny -Only 3 tables) and the parking situation (street parking/hard to find a park spot). Probably best to avoid the peak hours (dinner/lunch time).
author: Mai K.

description:
Unimpressed.

I like thin crust pizza, really, I do.  And the crust was good.  Unfortunately that was the only good thing about our dinner.  

Service is slow.  

Salads seem to be made too far in advance, then stocked in the beverage fridge.  Our "green salad" lettuce was wet, over-chilled/frozen.  

Pizza toppings were generous in amount, but with insufficient cheese.  Even on the cheese pizza.  The "slice of the day" was sliced (canned) black olives & chopped grape tomaotes just sprinkled onto a pre-baked piece of cheese pizza with nothing on top to bind them on.  Odd.  

And the pie options were unimaginative.
author: Laura K.

description: Was in here today and it seemed like it's undergoing a change in decor. Possibly personnel also? Not sure if that's a good or bad thing, but this place is consistent if nothing else. I've bumped them up a star from my previous review.
author: aaron f.

description: Great little hideaway spot. The meatball subs are to die for!!!
author: Sandra F.

description:
This place is not only great, but easy on your wallets. The price range for a slice is around $3-4 and a combo for about $5. 

Can't beat that, right?
 
The taste may be a little bland at first, but sprinkle a little Parmesan cheese or garlic powder to give it that burst of flavor. Good customer service is hard to find, but you can surely find it here. They are so friendly and make you feel so welcomed that you want to come back again.
author: Jennifer P.

description:
Unremarkable and disappointing.

I bought the Living Social deal ($15 for $30 credit) and thought I would give this place a whirl last night based on some of the very good reviews.

Price:  high
Service: slow
Quality:  unremarkable, needs more cheese
Portions:  good

The service was so poor that I had to bus the table clean in order for us to sit down.  There were about 3 other couples in the restaurant.  The pizza was very weak on cheese.  I think they needed to at least double the amount.  Yes, it is thin-crust, but the lack of cheese made the pizza taste way too doughy.  Plus, the plastic disposable water cups added that extra bit annoyance to make me not want to come back.

I don't know what some of the reviewers of this place are thinking.  Cybelle's and Gaspare's are far better, plus it is on the pricey end, especially for the little you get.
author: Dan A.

description: This 3.5 stars rating is bullshit!  If you like your pizza thin, with a crispy yet doughy crust, if you like your tomato sauce sweet and fresh and if you like your toppings amazing you might wanna go here.
author: Sebastian H.

description: So it's 12:05 on a Sunday night and I just saw a pizza get delivered to my neighbor. I tried to order a pizza last night, Saturday, at 9:15pm, and you said you could not deliver at that time, I ordered from another vendor. How much business are you losing?
author: Jonathan K.

description: Very inexpensive. Especially for San Francisco. The pizza itself was decent, nothing amazing but nothing awful. Really it comes down to the money. You get alot for your money here and it's quite filling. The cashier wasn't the friendliest and was a bit slow at completing my order.
author: Bibiano L.

description:
Okay, so I came to this place mainly because I was in the area, and had little money to spend. The prices of this place are decent, but still a bit high. The portions aren't too big at all (for a slice), BUT the pizza is AWESOME! The pepperoni is really weird because they are tiny little ones spread sporadically around the pizza, and one slice definitely WOULD NOT  fill you up. 

I love cheap and awesome pizza, but Pizzeria Avellino is not cheap, but it is awesome pizza. The area is pretty expensive in general, but should pizza ever be expensive?...I mean, it's pizza.

Pizzeria Avellino is delicious, but more like a $$ price rating. If you want to get your money's worth, get a whole pie.
author: Angelo C.

description:
Hands down the "worst" pizza I have ever had.  Frozen Red Baron Pizza is 10x more better!!!

So a quaint like corner pizzeria.  But other than the decor it all goes downhill.

The staff are handicapped... (not really but act like it).  They cannot take an order if their lives depended on it.

So my order was very simple.  Wanted a combo pizza with no olives, red onions and peppers added.

What I got was a pizza riddled with olives, no peppers, and probably the equivalent of 2 whole onions thrown on it.....

I don't recommend "anyone" go to this place.  Even with a discount coupon...

Ok fawkin drunk as a skunk and smoked some kush.  This fawkin pizza is the shyitt!!!!
author: Rigs R.

description:
I was on my way to the bank from work and wanted to get a bite to eat.  Liverpool Lil's was sounding good, but I didn't have the 30 minutes to wait for food.  Pizzeria Avellino was right up my alley,

I walked down the long hallway of a restaurant and took a peek at the menu board.  

I settled for a pepperoni pizza.  Oh and they sell 'em by the slice.  The "cook" pulled out an already prepped cheese slice and dealt pepperoni slices on top and tossed it in the oven.

I plopped down $3.85 and realized...I still had money left to stop by Starbucks for an iced coffee.

Thanks Pizzeria Avellino for comin' to the neighborhood!  I'll be seeing you soon.
author: Rochelle D.

description:
I'm currently yummin' down a XL cheese pizza with mushrooms. Yes ... I know what you might be thinking ... FATTY. Well, it's not just me, well ... maybe it is ... but can you blame me? Seriously this crispy, warm, savory pie is one to remember. I've had REALLLY good pizza. Pizza that won't make you "orgasmica" (they suck) but will make your toes curl. This pie is just short of that, but for 24$ what can you expect?

I'd recommend a whole pie, the -by the slice- pieces seem to be less than desirable because of their "not so fresh" nature. 

I ordered take-out, the guys were cool enough to bring it out to me after I paid because I was double parked in an illegal zone. I love the "I understand SF parking" look I got from the guy who offered. 

Overall, 5 for 5, they could use a little more ambiance, and a little less 64 signs highlighting their daily special / pizza by the slice price / whatever deal they have going.

FYI: They said 20 minutes, it was more like 32, so just show up a little later than they tell you for pickup. No worries, I got a few necessary phone calls in.
author: Chris S.

description:
There aren't too many places in San Francisco where you can get an honest thin crust New York style pizza. Pizzeria Avellino happens to be one of them, and it's sort of like my personal Arinell (http://www.yelp.com/biz/arinell-pizza-san-francisco#hrid:CfLFUNZvx7A2bhw0JOw11A) to the north. 

They also do a mean deep dish Sicilian style, which is hard to find in the city as well, so respect to that. My recommendation is to order a whole pie or wait for some fresh slices, order a glass of pinot and enjoy. Even better, go at happy hour where they have some good deals going on. 

I'm not sure of the exact relation to Italy but Avellino is a town in Southern Italy, as research professes (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Avellino).
author: Nish N.

description: My favorite San Francisco "fast food" is a slice of cheese pizza and coke in a can. Not the healthiest choice, but great when I've forgotten to eat lunch and am in the midst of a blood-sugar crash. Pizzeria Avellino is my current favorite go-to spot. The crust is thin with just the right crunchy crispiness without being hard. The sauce is really good and the cheese is nice and salty. The slices are pretty big, too. I get in and out of this place quickly, which helps because I'm constantly rushing during work hours. Pizza Avellino has ruined me from  being able to grab a quick slice anywhere else.
author: Robynne W.

description:
If you're familiar with Famous Joe's on Carmine at Bleecker, but stuck in San Francisco, give it a try out.

Pizzeria Avellino makes a great New York-style pizza pie, perfect thin crust -- best to stick to sausage, pepperoni, or straight up cheese.  Since it opened about 6 months ago, we've been regulars.  

Some of the order-taking dudes may be a bit off, but the pie maker / manager / owner? is usually there keeping relative order and making some excellent pizza.  Among the best you can find NY-style in the city.

Best certainly to consider a full pie, as a quick slice is bit steep.  If you can't eat the entire pie hot -- it's best served cold for breakfast the next day.  

We generally get it to go, with convenient parking / double-parking available -- but on a quiet weekend afternoon, it's not bad to sit and watch SportsCenter and listen to Pink Floyd or some 80s power rock.  Journey 'Don't Stop Believing' was playing the last time I visited -- that's worth a visit on its own, in my view.
author: James D.

description: No frills, but great slices. A great option in the neighborhood. Love the bell peppers and black olives.
author: Dan B.

description:
My wife and I walk our doggies over at the lawn across from the old Letterman/ New Lucas Arts building, and, seeing as I was born in NY (moved here when I was 3, folks are from Astoria and Flushing, and I lived on W47th and 9th for 5 years in the mid-80's) and my wife is from New York originally? We saw the sign and thought we'd see how their pies were. 
Wow. And not in a good way.
 I'm not a kid anymore, I'm 49. I was a punk rocker, a bike messenger,sang in a band called 'Ik Nak Fu' and grew up here in SF, and am not some kind of bitter Republican tool who doesn't care for dippy, monosyllabic, downright stupid and rude service staff. Avellino could have the most wonderful goddamn pizza on the planet (and it's NOT very good-inconsistent, made w/ little attention to balance or integrity for establishing and maintaining standard, decent flavors/seasoning/quality ingredients-it's really sucks-like red painted dough addled cardboard) and I would never step foot in it again. I tell anyone who asks to avoid the place like the plague, and that it was one of the most awful restaurant experiences in my entire life. If there is a god in heaven, the fool who owns it and staffs it with the most staggeringly complete collection of cretins and outright, really trying to be world class assholes will lose enough customers and be forced to go out of business and shut the door forever, ASAP. I'm serious-the little pimple headed shithead who grudgingly sneered at us and somehow found the strength to tell us that there was no menu, only the sandwich boards, after which he went back to ignoring us, the phone, the other customers, and his job description, something that he was VERY adept at- acting like a little shitheaded bitch. I really felt like vaulting the counter and smashing his  teeth down his arrogant throat, his attitude was so poor and his disdain for us so obvious. Hands down the worst trained staff I have EVER seen or dealt with-I read the reviews saying how wonderful this truly awful shithole is for 'families and kids'? Apparently penned by people who lack a set of standards that most sane people possess? Because this restaurant is the most egregious example of ignoring the importance of hiring good staff and training them to represent your business to the public in a positive way I have ever experienced-and I worked in the Food Service industry for over 25 years. Truly astonishing, the level of rudeness and apathy towards those who pay their salaries and pay the rent for this train wreck. The owner is an utter and complete fool for allowing this type of behavior to be the public 'face' for his subpar establishment. Avoid it at all costs! Shamefully amateur customer 'service' at this embarrassment to the good name of hardworking, upfront and positive, high energy New Yorkers everywhere. These phony, posing puds behind the counter? They wouldn't last 5 minutes in Manhattan-no freakin way.
author: Tim T.

description: On trip to San Francisco, we stopped by this pizza joint while visiting the Yoda Statue inside the Presido.  We ordered mushroom, pepperoni and sausage XL for 4 guys.  The slices were cut into big slices and it was just enough to fill us up.  The Pizza was had great thin crust and flavor.  The location is small with outdoor seating and no restrooms.  Definitely worth a stop if you are in the area.
author: Teddy A.

description: It was a busy day, but seriously? Ordered a sandwich...my friend order the same sandwich after me...he got his. When i finally went up to ask about my food, they inform me they are out of ingredients!  Really...you could not have told me that when you realized you didn't have any more meatballs? Basicially, idiots are working there.
author: Dilly M.

description: Great pizza, cool little setting, quick delivery if close by. Bottomless mimosas for a good price.
author: Guiseppi M.

description:
Perfect spot to grab some delicious thin crust, New York style pizza. The slices are cut large just like in New York. The best part is the pizza is not oily and crust is crispy so you don't need to fold the pizza in half to eat it. A much healthier version of NY pizza.

There are only a couple of pizza options, including pizza of the day special. They make the pizza when you order it, so it comes right out of the oven! We tried the vegetarian and Lombard. There's only two pie sizes available: L and XL. For 6 people we finished off 2 XL. The Lombard pizza is really good. The vegetarian was mediocre.

It's a small and narrow place. Fortunately it wasn't crowded when we came and was able to secure a table for our group. It seems to be a local favorite spot for many. The staff are really nice and cool.

A bonus is this is only 2 blocks away from the Palace of Fine Arts! It's perfect walking distance to go grab some food before a show.
author: Melissa T.

description: By far the best pizza I've had in sf yet and makes me feel like I'm back in manhattan thin and crispy crust....they get pizza
author: Alexander E.

description: Was minding my own biz heading to Liverpool Lils for lunch in Cow Hollow, when I passed by this lil' shop with the same yummy aroma of the pizza that I enjoyed as a kid in NYC in the '70s, wafting up to grab my attention.  A note on the door further confirmed my olfactory instincts when it read "Pizza by the Slice"!  I had to stop in.  After having now downed one slice of pepperoni and one of sausage, I can report that these guys nailed it.  All for the reasonable price of $3.70/slice ($3.20/slice for plain).  In speaking to the guy who appears to own the joint, he shared that he actually brought in a 30 year pizza making veteran from Manhattan who both made the pizzas for a while and taught the rest of his crew how to make the real thing.  The goal was excellently achieved.
author: P W.

description: Had another cheese slice, very mediocre. Even with lots of seasoning I couldn't finish it. The crust though is thin, crispy and not wet at all. But the cheese seems really low quality. Curious about the napolatena pies but otherwise I am done with this place. If you want NY style go to Arinell's on Valencia in the Mission. End of story.
author: casey c.

description:
My daughter and I went to use a Living Social voucher.  We were very pleased with our experience.

The restaurant is pretty small and clearly a neighborhood favorite.  There were families with small kids, so it was noisy but not unpleasantly so.

The pizza is New York style thin crust, lightly sauced.  I tried to show my daughter how to roll a slice, but she refused.

I had the Lombard Combo with pepperoni, sausage, mushrooms and olives.  It was really good, with a perfect balance of ingredients.  My daughter had a simple cheese pizza and loved it.

I will gladly go there again if I am in the neighborhood at a mealtime, discount voucher or not.
author: Stuart C.

description:
This is the best sf pizza has to offer. Amazing crust, generous amounts of cheese, great sauce. Big slices. 

My advice. Buy a pie. Pig out on it and eat leftovers the next day. Its great reheated as well. 

You will not have any pizza order regret if you go here.
author: Guy K.

description:
We have been using Avellinos ever since it opened a few years ago.  We live right nearby and usually just pick up an XL pizza, or sometimes bring the whole family in and eat there.  The pizza is always delicious.  Great crust, great sauce.  

They are very reliable with our orders and eating there is always a pleasant experience.
author: K S.

description:
After nearly four years of dealing with the frustration getting unbelieveably bad pizza in the Oakland area from pizzerias purporting to sell "New York Pizza", I was amazed, delighted, and overjoyed to finally find the real deal at Avellino's.

This is some of the best pizza I have ever had, in NY or elsewhere, and it is the totally authentic, thin, crispy, crusted pizza that I grew up with in Brooklyn.

Best of all, it's walking distance from my office ... Now, to see if they do an eggplant parmigiana!
author: Doug L.

description: Used to like it but the last few times it tasted no better than cardboard!
author: Nipul C.

description:
I grab a couple of slice-o-the-day's here once or twice a month and they have always been perfectly prepared. Crust is perfect thick/thinness (for me) and the sauce has got that something that most places are lacking. It is really all about the sauce and the crust when it comes to satisfying my pizza craving. I like that they have a nice happy hour deal and the TV always has a game on or ESPN. It's close to work and a nice break from the "regular" places on Chestnut. The pepperoni and bacon is a great duo as well as the meatball and whatever. Slices are huge and the one time I bought a large, I had to fend off people on BART trying to stand close to me just to smell the goodness. 
Finally a quality place to eat at that perfect corner location. Sorry LiverpoolLil, but a $13 Burger just can't compete with a slice and a beer for $7or $8. Hope they have continued success!
author: Randy S.

description:
Yelp app to the rescue! My girlfriend and I were ravenous after spending a few hours at the Renegade Craft Fair. I whipped out my phone, checked my bookmarks on my Yelp app and we were on our way to Pizzeria Avellino. 

I went for two generous sized pizza of the day slices. The meaty version and a veggie option with peppers, jalapenos and olives. While the toppings weren't anything super special, I thought the crust was flavorful and crispy and it really made the entire pizza eating experience for me.

This is a real pizza joint, complete with a loud football game on TV.
author: Lee H.

description:
This is a great venue, great location and this city is in dire need of amazing pizza. I just have to remind myself I am not in NY...

The owner and staff were super friendly and hospitable.

A few things that can be improved:

1. The cheese overpowers the pizza, I did not taste the tomato sauce pop through as you should in a NY slice.

2. Uniformity in "slice" construction could be improved. There were thick and thin places in the dough which causes the slice to fall apart while you are eating it. 

3. The taste of the dough was very bland. In my opinion the dough is the canvas and should hold up to all ingredients that are put on the pizza. Needs a bit more flavor.

Hoping to be pleasantly surprised on my next visit...
author: Petra J.

description: It was like eating a pretzel with pizza topping. The sauce is very light. The crust tho....WOW! It is thin, crispy, soft, not chewy at all. For how thin it is I was surprised how well a big slice for $3.95(btw) held a stiff but soft form.
author: kristina T.

description:
Never going back to this place again. EVER.

ok people the Pizza isn't that special, go try it for yourself and compare it to Amici's or your favorite Pizzeria.  

WITHOUT going into details, i'm just going to relate my experience to this Seinfeld episode ""The Soup Nazi ""..."NO SOUP FOR YOU!!" NOW GET OUT.  This sums it up.  Obviously, the owners that work here, (yes for those who did not know, the owners actually work here, no one at Avellino will tell that because they're all related to one another, and don't want to deal with the a concerned or mistreated customer.  Anyhow, they do not appreciate the fact that we (the customers) coming into this place and giving them business by choosing to eat here instead of going to any of their 100s of competitors across town.  They won't know what a customer's worth until they start loosing tens or hundreds of them... 

Good luck going there because you will be humiliated, embarrassed and yelled at even when you're not alone and with a bunch of colleagues from work.

BTW:  Have i mentioned that, nothing special about the pizza here. Actually Amici's pizza tops Avellino and waaayy better.
author: Enga G.

description: Being a New Yorker on vacation, I'm always wary of pizzerias that advertise "New York Style." But I was hungry, and the reviews seemed great.  It was absolutely amazing. The slices were big and thin like what I'm used to on Long Island, the cheese was gooey, and best of all, the pizza was greasy. Obviously, pizza is better in New York; but this is by far the best pizza I've ever had outside of the Big Apple.
author: TJ C.

description: All round good pie; the guys that work there are super nice too.
author: Drew V.

description:
They really hit it on the crust: truly delicious!
But the toppings are so, so, cheap it's a shame to put so little on a pizza... although at least you can really taste the crust!!!
author: Elle H.

description:
I ate a few slices here tonight with "Must Love Pork" who also wrote a review.  #1, I am from Brooklyn where the world's best Pizza exists.  #2, I've never sat an establishment and been so amazed at the actions of the staff as I did tonight, so much so that we didn't say a word to each other, no words needed to be spoken.  If you've read the book "Blink" by Malcolm Gladwell, you'll know what I mean when I say the moment I walked in within a split second I felt something was wrong.  It was instinctual.  Something didn't feel right, I felt totally unwelcome.  The negative energy from the guy behind the counter was so bad, I had to ask the pizza maker guy if they were still serving pizza, and he said yes.  The pizza maker guy was the 'nice guy' relatively speaking.  The guy who took our order, the punk wearing the beanie, rang me up and seemed liked I was totally inconveniencing him.  But it gets better...

I ALWAYS tip no matter where I go, 10% minimum if the person simply serves me food.  After he ran me up, I had $1.50 of change in my hand, and promptly put it in my pocket.  I reiterate what 'Must Love Pork' wrote.  This same kid was throwing the trays and plates in the back area, totally pissed at the customers who were sitting in there eating.  He was sweeping the floors aggressively near my feet to send me a message.  Then he stood over the restaurant with arms crossed, facing the two tables left, with a scowl on his face, waiting for us to leave.  Holy sh*t, I couldn't believe what I was watching.  Being from NYC I was inclined to confront this child, but it was better to leave him to continue his tantrum.  As I walked out past him, I still expected someone had taught this guy the standard "Thank you", but got nothing, not a word.  As I was reeling in even this last omission, I got a big "Wham" as the door slammed behind me.  Unbelievable.  I actually laughed it was so astonishing.

I feel better that I didn't say anything, because I know it was purely horrible customer service on his end, I didn't instigate anything, was a display of poor management of employees, despite decent pizza.  I would fire this guy so fast and not think about reprimanding him because it isn't worth the time.  That's an inherent understanding of customer service that he can't be taught.  Send him to a skate board shop to work the back room.

Back to Amici's, or anywhere else!
author: Charles G.

description: We got delivery of Avellino last night and it was quite good.  I like thin crust pizza but may have to try the Sicilian style sometime.  A plus is that it's much cheaper than Amici's.
author: Denise G.

description:
Terrible cardboard crust, fresh toppings, and meh cheese.  Not really any great flavors or taste.  Price is not too bad at 3.50/ slice.

Nice guys that work there, good music, nice atmosphere.  Just prepared to not be wow'ed by the actually pizza.
author: Rob R.

description: Love the pizza here! Reminds me of pizza place back in Boston!  I wish they delivered to SOMA
author: Tommy W.

description:
"I SAY GOD DAMN GOD DAMN!"

MY favorite line in Pulp Fiction when Mia Wallace is doing a line of blow in the bathroom. 

Pizzeria Avellino is the first true slice of New York Pizza (sorry Arnelle Lovers, this place is better) I have ever had in San Francisco. Thin, tangy and the cheese was perfect. 

Mark my words this place is going to blowup big. Get there now, get there fast. 

Small, quaint and delicious. Great place for a chill date.

Met the owner, the man is a true pizza lover and it shows. 

My only complaint:

Like another reviewer pointed out, I also think that in a green city like San Fracisco, you gotta go with real plates, silver ware and napkins. Get rid of the paper plates. I know, they don't do it like that in NY, but you are in one of the greenest most progressive cities in the world.
author: D M.

description: Great pizza and specials, plus awesome location right outside the Presidio park. Good service from the guys working there and cool atmosphere overall.
author: Jordan A.

description:
Today was my first time eating here. The fam and I hung out in the Presidio for quality lazy Sunday time, but we needed quick lunch without having to walk deep into the Marina for it. 

Come Pizzeria Avellino. My first impression was this place was pricey; a cheese slice + soda for $4?? I've seen them for $2 in other places. Hubby pointed out we were in such neighborhood. 

Well, we ordered a medium Lombard combo. At $17, this was a pleaser! Truly a medium sized pizza, this was worth every bite. Compared to Extreme Pizza, whose large is pretty much a medium to me, this was priced fairly.  Between 2 adults and a toddler, we had plenty to eat. Our second child is just a baby so she didn't have any, but she was happy with her milk. 

I can't give this place 5 stars only because there weren't that many options and they don't offer drinks by the pitcher. We recently had pizza at Dino's on Fillmore and I was spoiled by the pitchered drink to drown my pizza down. Avellino's, if you could even just offer a pitchered drink, I'd upgrade this review to 4.5 stars. 

Overall, a great pizza for reasonable price! We'll come back again.
author: Anio D.

description: This weekend was my second trip to Pizzeria Avellino, the first time just stopped in to grab a beer ever since I had been waiting to go back and try a slice. Amazing is the only word. I got a slice of sausage, the crust was thin and crispy, the sausage was spicy.....perfection. This pizza is only second to Mack & Mancos at the Jersey Shore in my opinion.
author: Heathet B.

description:
I'm originally from the east coast and have had my fair share of slices. This is by far the best pizza I've had since I've moved to the city.

I've ordered from Pizzeria Avellino a couple of times now and it's always been a wonderful experience.  Their delivery is super fast and they put Parmesan and peppers in the box.  

The staff is awesome!  It was a great place to take my family. When I stopped by after a day out in the Presidio, my daughter was pretty fussy and hungry. The employee who took our order provided my daughter with a coloring book and crayons and turned the TV to cartoons to calm her down. Awesome!

The pizza is fan-tastic! Always fresh and tasty, they have a great thin crust. The toppings are generous and delicious. I love the Lombard pizza. It's a family favorite.  They also serve coffee in the morning, so I'm gonna stop by for a cappuccino after my run.

Overall, tasty affordable pizza and friendly staff. I will be there again soon!
author: Tiffany J.

description:
What an awesome pizza place!  I usually am not a huge fan of pizza, unless it's some fancy deep dish Zachary's or super Berkeley Cheeseboard, but wow, I was super impressed.

It was a somewhat dry night on Friday, and me and my friends needed some food near Palace of Fine Arts Theater.  We had a few choices, but went for Pizzeria Avellino.  What a perfect choice!

The service was very nice, the people there were very warm and polite.  There were two families there eating, and a long bar with stools, but not at all crowded on a Friday night.

We were able to get a table of six people, and our pizza was just fantastic.  Not oily, and didn't just crumble.  The crust was firm enough to hold up and did not need the half fold to eat.

I really liked the sauce and toppings.  I'm a huge fan!  I'm going there again!!  The best NY Pizzas I've had in SF so far!
author: Art C.

description: Okay place, pizza and one beer for $7 damn good but you get what you paid for.  I had pizza that was not cook all the way so I had to send it back but they fix it right.
author: Chris A.

description:
Finally!  A yummy and affordable restaurant at this location.  And the pizza is delicious.  I love the hot, crispy, cheesyness that Avellino delivers. I've lived in the Presidio for 6 years now and the previous incarnations at this location have been soooooo blah.  

I especially love the sauce. It's not as heavy as other restaurants, a little tangy, light, just plain delicious.  Not only is it affordable, not heinously expensive, but it's freaking good for thin crust pizza.  I would give it 5 stars, but since I've never had true NY style pizza, I can't make that assessment.  (*hangs head in shame*)

Thank you Avellino for moving in!! We Marin-ites neeeded you.
author: Joanne D.

description: Best pizza in the city behind little star, IMO. Great staff, too.
author: Dev S.

description: This is a solid local pizza place with New York style slices and pies. Yum!
author: Kate R.

description: Their pizza is okay if you're stuck in the Presidio.  It's quite authentic as far as cheap New York-style pizza goes, but that's not really a good thing in my book.  They're cheap and friendly and so on but frankly I think their stuff is kind of bland.  Not worth going out of your way for.
author: J S.

description:
I first stumbled onto Pizzeria Avellino on their Opening Week, crowded and the pizza was awesome. You know how sometimes new places open with great food, then later it sucks, I happened to be in the Marina last weekend and decideed to try it again, to see if it kept up with the quality................Oh Yeah, you can get no better anywhere in the City (My Opinion ;)). The pizza was thin, crispy like no other, the sauce and toppings doesn't overwhelm the best pizza crust around. Add a beer and you're good.

I was fooled I was eating "pizza"  from all these other pizza places (thick undercooked dought for crust, thick sauce to mask the crust) all these years.

No more, there is now real pizza in the City, and it's here at Pizzeria Avellino. I live in Glen Park and there is no hesitation going across town to the best pizza.

All I've got to say................."Try Some Real Pizza!"
author: Francisco M.

description: This is place is legit New York style pizza! I hear they got their pizza maker from Arinel at 16th and Valencia in the Mission, and if you live in SF you know that's legit NY style as well.  My slice was hot and fast, easy place for lunch.  The employees have always been friendly with me; I've probably been in 4 or 5 times in the past few months cause its next door to my work. Never had any of the issues some other yelpers have had with service. Crust is right on and some of the different combo are money.  bacon garlic is awesome.  the (sliced) meatballs are good too.  I'd start with a classic cheese slice for my first time and move on from there.
author: John D.

description: Another mediocre pizza that makes me wonder why I even bother to try pizza in SF anymore.  After waiting the obligatory hour for delivery I was rewarded with a pie that would have tasted a lot better if they had taken it out of the oven earlier.  The pizza was greasy and the crust dry and hard like a breadstick.
author: Lisa K.

description:
Avellino, it shows great promise, it does!

Is it NY-style pizza?  Absolutely.  You grab the sail-sized slice off of the paper plate, fold in half, watch the oil drip down the crease, and have all the sights and sounds of Bleecker Street come flooding back into your mind.  

Is it really good NY-style pizza?  Meh.  The crust is fine, but it misses that magical balance of crunch and chew that would make me want to transfer 2 trains and then stand on line (only California hippies stand *in* line) for 15 minutes.  If they reduce the thickness a smidgen and tone down the crunch, I think they've got a pie that would make a New Yorker wicked proud.
author: John H.

description:
Tried this place out for the first time today to fulfill my extreme hunger resulting from a terrible hangover (thanks halloween!).  I ordered a 'Greco' for pickup.  They were out of pine nuts, so I just got it minus that garnish.  Pizza was on time, but a couple of pieces got squashed in the box that was too small for the pizza.

I liked my pizza.  The crust had a great texture, but a little flavorless.  I think most of the sauce on the pizza was pesto, but there was some red sauce.  The red sauce was way too sweet - they need to add some salt to their marinara!

Pizzetta kicks this places ass, but I would definitely consider getting pizza from here again since I live close by.
author: Ali G.

description: Eh. It seems like it's going to be an awesome little hole in the wall, but it's nothing special.
author: Danielle B.

description:
I lived near NYC for almost 2 years, and fell in love with NY-style pizza.  Grabbed two slices of the daily special (meatlovers) to go. Nice big slices, good authentic crust. Sauce is less than I expected, but the fat slices, crust quality, and liberal toppings density was good.

I shall be back. Welcome, Avellino, to the neighborhood.
author: Neil H.

description:
I ordered a new york style pizza to go tonight, for me and my husband, who's coming down with a cold.

It was, in a word, delightful.  The crust is thin and a little crunchy, not chewy and gross (my pet peeve).  By crust, I'm referring not just to the part on the outside, but the part under the toppings as well.  It was great.  Also, I thought the sauce was just right, the cheese wasn't too greasy, etc, etc.  Why analyze too much? I don't know why it was so good, it just was.

Incidentally, the pizza was huge- a new york style pizza is probably eight of those huge slices, and will feed four hungry people.  Not bad for 20 bucks. 

I have a  feeling that the napolitana style will also be fantastic; a whole different culinary experience.  

I'm really psyched this place exists.  It's definitely worth a try!
author: Melinda A.

description: I have to disagree with the NY-ers on this page who said this is legit NY pizza. I totally disagree. The sauce was not sweet, like east coast pizza. i grew up in the EC & know my pizza. This does not compare. Dry crust, un-sweet sauce does not = NY pizza. I am convinced there is no NY pizza in NYC and just have come to grips with it. I get my fill when I am home on the east coast.
author: Heather M.

description:
I had a great two slices at avellino the other day while waiting for my friend to get out of work. Everyone there was really nice and i could sit outside at there benches and eat a slice in nice weather.  The Pizza was definitly comparable to east coast pizza as I could find in the city and I will definitly return. I give it 4.5 stars because Im really picky about the pizza I eat. 

I just wanted to comment on a previous yelpers remarks and so I sent him a message. Message is below. 

Thanks Avellino for some good grub. 

Mr. G.

I just wanted to comment on your remarks about Avellinos. Your obviously a competitor of this place and your attempts to belittle them are quite lame and pathetic. 

Business is business I know, but i went to Avellinos the other day and was very impressed by both the pizza and the staff. 

Congratulations, your another hoighty doighty loser who has spent time in Italy. Were all very impressed. What you dont know is that like every other place in the world, every town has different styles within themselves. If every place in Avellino is the same, I would rather not visit. 

Why dont you just run your own business whatever it may be and let these people make the pizza they have set out to make. ITs damn good to me and I havnt had much good pizza out here yet. ..Including Pizaa Delfino. 

On a side note: Your picture is Awesome...ha ha
author: Scott H.

description: My first trip to Pizzeria Avellino was during its first week of opening. They had tasty gourmet pizzas and great Italian thin crust but after a few weeks they decided to cater to a simpler pallet. I am glad they are still in biz and I enjoy the place for the convenient location and nice staff.
author: Chelsea M.

description:
we used our freshguide coupon here. it was $10 for $20 worth of food and drinks. pretty good deal. i had a couple slices of the sicilian(cheese). not nearly as good as golden boy, but a solid pizza. there was a lot of cheese but the sauce wasn't the most flavorful. $3.50 is a decent price and the bridge of my mouth thanks them for serving it up at the perfect temperature.

i didn't try the ny thin slice, but it didn't look that good. i think the sicilian is probably wayyy better here. happy hour meant $2 beers, which is awesome. so for the $10, we got 3 slices and 4 beers. i can't complain too much :)
author: Andrew T.

description: Very good for just a plain cheese slice. Anything else I've had there I've not been impressed with. Especially their deep dish - not good at all. Definately not my first choice when going out for pizza.
author: Charlotte P.

description: This town is starving for good East Coast pizza. We have lived here for 6 months and finally have found our place. Thin, light and tasty, if you like that this is your place. Be sure to fold when you eat.
author: Brett J.

description:
The Pizzeria is amazing. Loved the pizza sauce, a taste of heaven.
Making this place a solid number one choice for future pizza lunch and dinners meals.
author: Daniel G.

description:
Really good pizza.  Great service.  Neat ambiance.  And they'll have beer & wine in just a few weeks.  What more could you ask for?  We spent time talking with one of the owners (Steve) and he told us he and his business partner had dreamed of starting their own pizza place for years and they were so pumped to finally do it.  They're working day jobs and manning the fort by night.  It's hard not to get fired up by passionate entrepreneurs, good prices, and a really good product.

We'll definitely be back!
author: Collin H.

description: If it is a nice day in San Francisco there isn't a better place to grab a breakfast pizza, bottomless mimosas, and sit right outside the Presidio.  I frequent this place probably a little too much.
author: Glenn V.

description: Thank you FRESH GUIDE coupons for introducing me to Pizzeria Avellino! Great NYC style pizza. I am always up for a deal and bought the Fresh Guide deal- you know the $10 for $20 worth of pizza type of deal. LOVE IT! Great place and very friendly! We ordered pizza for take out and OMG amazing. Well I was moving apartments so my mover boys I recruited to help before my actual movers came really enjoyed the pizza- I know we were starving and anything would taste good- but Pizza Avellino really is good!
author: Kimberly M.

description:
Every New Yorker knows the pizza in SF is terrible. Most of our neighbors don't even know what they are missing.  I have grumbled about it for years.  
Thank goodness for Pizzeria Avellino.  They serve delicious New York style thin crust pizza that you can fold and eat.  At last!  If I close my eyes I almost think I'm having a slice "in the city that never sleeps".  Brava!
author: A. F.

description: A cool little place tucked into the end of Lombard street.  It's $3.00 for cheese slice which is big and thin, crispy crust and good ration of sauce to cheese (Like more cheese than sauce).  A long thin building with plenty of room to sit and eat in.  Beer and wine.  I snagged the window seat and had a great time.
author: Jeff J.

description: I used to work near this pizza place, and I thought it was just ok. Nothing really special about it. Its cool that they sell slices of pizza and they are pretty cheap - so for quick, cheap, ok pizza it was fine. But it wasnt great or nearly as good as any pizza I've had ...and nothing compared to the pizza I had in NYC. Plus if you order anything other than cheese they will just throw on toppings and toss it in the oven to "warm it up" when you order a slice..not exactly the best quality
author: Kimberly R.

description: I really did want to like this place but it was a no go. It was bland and boring. If you go to Trader Joe's and get their pizza dough I promise you can fix something up at home in 10 minutes that tastes better.
author: Amy M.

description:
My hubby is part Italian and from the NY area.  He has always loved a good thin crust pizza; definitely not a fan of deep dish.  I'm not Italian and have only visited the NY area.  I've always loved a tasty pizza; however, I've always leaned towards the thin crust side over the doughy deep dish style pizza.  We're a match made in pizza heaven.  

I was craving pizza one day after watching a television show where the characters were macking on some slices. The hubby and I are always looking for some good NY style pizza so I turned to fellow Yelpers to help us out.  Pizza Avellino popped up first and we scurried on the bus in hopes of filling our tummies with deliciousness.

* Space:  Although there are less than a dozen tables inside, the place is quaint and definitely good for eating a few slices.  Also, there's a TV over the door that can keep you preoccupied while waiting for your food if you're alone or the company you came with isn't entertaining enough.
* Atmosphere:  The place smells of deliciousness and gives off a homely vibe.  You walk in and immediately can see them making the pies and salads in the back.  
* Drink: You can get canned or bottled sodas and wine or beer.  Although the wine list isn't extensive, it's a refined list for the size the place.  
* Eat:  We got a simple medium pepperoni pie.  It was served up piping hot from the oven and had the right ratio of cheese:sauce and a great crispy crust. The pepperoni's were nickel sized (not a big deal, although I like the bigger slices) and there were a good amount on each slice.
* Service:  The guys greeted us in a friendly manner immediately upon stepping into the place.  They offered suggestions, told us how long it would take for our pie to come out, brought the tableware and pie when it was fresh out of the oven.  

Overall:  I'd say it's well worth your money to get a pie over a slice or two (even if you have to take some home).  Although it was out of the way for us, the ride over was definitely nice on a clear day through the Presidio.  I would definitely make the trek again to try some of their other pies.
author: melinda m.

description: On the verge between unremarkable and meh. The service is fine, and the decor is average and all that, but the pizza is mediocre and overpriced. If it were cheaper, I'd be able to overlook the blandness, and if it were tastier, the price might be acceptable. As it is 4 bucks/slice is a lot. They get a star for convenience, in that they're one of the few places that's convenient and quick for lunch if you work in the presidio (one of the few places for lunch period, really). But yeah. I certainly wouldn't come here if I didn't have to, there are far better pizza places around the city (arinell's on valencia is my personal favorite)
author: Jeremy G.

description: well, the name and the positive Yelp's reviews tricked me. I thought this place was managed by Italians but it's not and you can simply understand that by ordering their expensive, bland, flavorless pizza. My husband ordered the whole sausage pie and I ordered a slice of cheese. The owner didn't mention that was way too much pizza for too and charged my husband 2$ for the onions (extra topping). So my husband ended up paying 19$ for 8 slices of pizza...bland flavorless pizza. The only good point is the crust, well cooked and crispy. No flavor nor salt in the tomato sauce and no flavor in the cheese. Won't go back. This place is too expansive and lack of flavors overall !
author: Biemme B.

description: I just tried their new breakfast pizza they started making on the weekends. AWESOME, AWESOME, AWESOME!!!  Eggs, cheese, bacon, sausage, hashbrowns, perfectly cooked crust, I mean thin, crispy but not overcooked. As I understand, they are now doing brunch from 10am to ? on Saturday and Sunday with bottomless mimosa's priced at 5 bucks! I've had their regular New York style pizza and I'd have to say that the B-fast pizza is definately my fave!!!
author: Raymond A.

description:
Hi folks,
I am compelled to update this review. As of late, it seems that ALL of the pizza coming from Avellino is reheated, which is UNCOOL.

A couple of days ago, my neighbor and I ordered a medium pizza. As I mentioned in my original review, pizza by the slice was already cooked and reheated, but ordering a whole pizza guaranteed a fresh pie. This is no longer the case. Our medium pizza was obviously a pizza that had been cooked as a cheese pizza, and then reheated with our desired toppings. It was very evident by the fact that my "extra cheese" was a completely different color and state of melt than the original cheese.  In addition, there were also strange bits of sausage, as if cooked sausage had been removed at some point. Again, UNCOOL.

We brought the pizza back to the store (we discovered this atrocity after we walked home with it). When we confronted the workers, they were saying one thing, then contradicting themselves, about how all of the pizza is half baked, and then toppings are added halfway through the cooking. Of course, this makes no sense -- would you add only cheese, and then add "extra cheese" and toppings halfway through the cook cycle? Preposterous. All of the NYC pizzerias I know will cook a pizza, with your desired toppings, from beginning to end when you order an entire pie. We could only surmise that Avellino bakes a lot of cheese pizzas in advance, and then reheats them, which is abominable. Tolerable for slices, but not OK for full pies. This was confirmed by the rack of cooked and now cold pizzas we saw in a rack next to the preparation area. We ordered a pizza at 7pm -- are they cooking these pizzas at 3pm and letting them sit for hours? WTF?

They agreed to make us a new pizza. When the new pizza came out, it looked exactly the same as the first one (minus the sausage bits). Very disappointing. And it tasted just like it looked -- superficially hot crust, but not hot, melted cheese stretching everywhere, like one would expect from a fresh pizza. Again, a formerly cheese pizza that they had added toppings to and reheated. Shameful!

In light of this, I am on a pizza boycott from this establishment. They were my favorite place and now I won't even set foot in there. It's a real shame, as I live very close by and was so excited when they opened up, and told all of my friends to come to the Marina for pizza. Now, I feel a responsibility to tell them to take their business elsewhere.

This is, indeed, a very sad day.

PS - they are also charging $2.75 for a 16oz of coke -- the liquor store next door sells the same for $1.75.
author: rachel s.

description:
They changed their menu, and got rid of the proscuitto, 4 cheese, and greco.  All they have in NY style pizza now.  

This place was awesome when it had the rustic pizzas.  

Now it is just well, avoidable.
author: Lexi V.

description:
I was so hopeful....but:

BLAND.  Boring, no flavor.  I have better frozen pizza than this.  Extremely disappointing.  If you've got no other choice, it's edible, but you won't be wowed.
author: A H.

description: I'm not really a pizza lover but since my boss told me to order it for the office for Halloween, I did.  We ordered the regular cheese & sicilian pizza. The sicilian pizza was so good, very cheesy all around and it just melted it in your mouth. I will definitely go back again =)
author: Yoshi L.

description: There slices are GREAT.  Thin crust, perfectly done, $3.  The decor is really cute and they play awesome music.  Definitely my new go-to for pizza in the marina.
author: Allison C.

description: I'm from NJ... as close to east coast pizza as you're going to find out here. It's good enough to fill my craving without having to fly back east haha
author: Jared A.

description:
Quality, VERY good pizza.  We had the NY-style cheese and the Neapolitan-style greek pizza.  Both were excellent.  

My only recommendation to the owners would be to use real plates/silverware and consider putting some salads on the menu.

Glad to have you in the neighborhood!
author: Emilie L.

description: WOW- Just got back from eating a slice at this place. Walked in at 8:45pm (15 minutes before they closed), and the guy working was CLEARLY not happy that we were there. He was in the middle of his closing duties and while we waited for our pizza, he wanted everyone to know that he had somewhere else to be. Dishes were tossed into the bins carelessly and  it was so loud, I actually couldn't carry on a conversation with my fiance. We sat there quietly and cringed every time dishes and pizza pans slammed against each other. He actually threw his side towel across the room into the cashier station, obviously mad that we walked in right before closing. The icing on the cake was when he stood near our table, WITH HIS ARMS CROSSED and waited until we were so uncomfortable, we had no other choice but to grab our sodas and leave. I walked out pissed off, ahead of my fiance and as we walked out of the door (no "good-bye, or "thanks") HE SLAMMED THE DOOR ON US!!!! Seriously?!?! In this city, where there are a BILLION other places to eat pizza???? We usually go to Amici's but decided to try a new place after a game of bowling in the Presidio. My advice: Go to Amici's, Pizza Orgasmica, Extreme Pizza...Taco Bell...WHEREVER...but DO NOT bother with this place. Even though Taco Bell chicken has more hormones then my birth control pill, I'd be willing to risk the hormonal fluctuation then to actually pay money for someone to piss me off. I work in the food industry and have never encountered such an angry, disrespectful cashier/server. The only time I have experienced such poor customer service in San Francisco is at the DMV.  I wanted to give this place a chance but sadly, not only was I disappointed but I was actually offended. Good luck with your business model, Pizzeria Avellino.
author: Must Love P.

description: Craving pizza on a Sunday afternoon, was heading to Pizzeria Delfina but came here on a whim simply because well, I hadn't been here before.  Plus the reviews on yelp had a lot of five stars.  They've only been open 3 weeks.  They sell pizza by the slice.  Had a mushroom slice ($3.50, I think). Seemed decent.  A good snack, esp. if you find yourself right by the presidio gates.  The tomato sauce could have used a bit more spice/salt--it was a bit bland.  I like escape from NY pizza better, which is slightly thinner crust than this place.  This is a good for a quick, fast bite.
author: Caroline I.

description: Some of the best pizza I've had in SF. Different from its peers, in a good way. Crust is the right combination of crunchy yet doughy. Red sauce is perfect for my taste: a tad bit sweet but tangy, too. Have only actually dined in-house once; we primarily do take-out instead. I'm very glad they've joined the neighborhood!
author: Tilden K.

description: Bought a pizza here and it was so awful that we couldn't even finish it, and I am pretty easy to satisfy with pizza.   There was barely anything on top of the crust, be it sauce, cheese or the supposed four extra $2/each toppings that we paid for.   The slices were very large, and only had about 3 olives, 2 mushrooms, 2 pieces of sausage each.  Couldn't even taste the 4th extra item (garlic).   Skimpy and tasteless.    You're better off buying a frozen pizza at the supermarket.   Go to Toto's, Mr. Pizza Man, North Beach (or anywhere) for better pizza.
author: Amhelia G.

description: Awesome pizza!  I stopped by only a few days after the place opened and was surprised at how "seasoned" the pizza was.  Great balance of flavor...sauce was mellow with just enough zing, toppings were tasty and well proportioned.  Makes my mouth water as I write this review.  I will be back next chance I get.
author: Tom M.

description: Been meaning to try this place forever and just got around to it this weekend.  Best pizza I've had in SF in a long time that doesn't fall into the fancy pizza category (gialina, A16, delfina, etc).  If you want a really good, super fresh tasting, straight up pizza this is about as good as it gets.
author: Eamonn T.

description:
Growing up in NYC, I have tasted some of the best pizza. 

Moved out here to SF 14 yrs ago  and yes there is some awesome cuisine out here, the pizza sucks!! 

That is till now. This place is the real deal. The sauce, the crust, the feel!! AMAZING!!! 

If you do not find this place amazing, you do not know what pizza is.
author: Cow H.

description: 3.5 stars for taste, but upped to 4 because i used my living social coupon and it was such a good deal! one M with red onions, garlic, mushroom and tomato and one XL meat lover for less than $35. five of us ate to gluttony stuffedness and took home a few slices for the next day. cold pizza for breakfast, what could be better?! well, winning the lottery, but not that much else.
author: Suana W.

description: Pure and simple, one of the best slices of NY-style pizza in our fair city.  Sure you can get excellent CA-style personal pizzas at a dozen places, but NY-style?  By the big-a$$ slice?  This is one of maybe only three places I have found that bring me back to NYC and Jersey.
author: Sweet B.

description: Bought the Living Social deal and ordered cheese pizza. No, this is not authentic NYC pizza. I actually kind of feel bad for the people who think it is. The pizza was overcooked - black in spots on the crust which was way too thin and the cheese was scare, and because of it being overcooked the cheese was "welded" on -- best way I can describe it. It was like the Domino's Extra Thin Crust, really. It was dry. I wanted the drip, drip, drip of the oil coming off some gooey melted cheese. A fluffy, doughy crust that tears off easily. The sauce had a pretty good flavor so it gets a couple stars for that.
author: PudgesGirl P.

description: Great pizza. I've lived in ny d this is the real deal. You could take a date, or If your solo, fold it and crush it. Either way, check it out.
author: mark l.

description: Good place to get take-out... almost a hole in the wall place (it's narrow but cheery inside), friendly people behind the counter.  I wouldn't travel across the city for it or anything but since I walk by this place a lot, I have been in for a thin crust cheese slice and it's not bad.  This week, I had a Sicilian slice which is a thicker crust pizza (sold by the slice only, I think) and I liked it better than their thin crust pizza.  It was crisp and had a ton of cheese.   I can't point out anything unique-- it's plain jane pizza, but at the same time, there isn't much to complain about.
author: Kari L.

description:
As a native New Yorker, I have searched for the best slice in SF for 12+ years.  I'd say I've finally found it.  In addition, the rumor that SF water won't produce NY pizza crust was debunked by the pizza-maker himself (and, of course, his pizza).  

The space itself is simple, small and clean.  They also deliver.

Spread the word!
author: Kingman G.

description: For a straight out-of-the-box pizza Avellino is the best! I like both the thin crust and siciian. The dough has a nice rounded taste (pun intended!) and the guys in the back are fun to hang out with while you wait. Viva Avellino!
author: Felix R.

description: This place replaced some nasty taco place whose enchiladas tasted microwaved.  Thank goodness it's a decent neighborhood pizza place where I can get a big slice, that's near my house.  It's thin crust, just the right amount of chewy yet crispy, and the workers are always really friendly.  It's not fancy or the best pizza in the city, but it's good enough when you want pizza fast and convenient-- it's better than gross amici's tasteless thin crust.  Their topping choices are standard, and the amount not extremely generous nor sparse.
author: James B.

description:
So happy to welcome Pizzeria Avellino to the neighborhood!  Despite some first day hiccups, the service couldn't have been nicer, and the pizza was delicious.  Two kinds: New York style and Italian (Neapolitan) with great toppings.  The formaggio is particularly good.  
Looking forward to seeing beer & wine and a salad on the menu in the near future.
author: Lauren J.

description: pizza is OK but they get the one star for FALSE ADVERTISING on their happy hour.  As stated it's $2 for domestic beers.  TWICE now I've ordered domestic beers (once blue moon, the other Gordon Biersch) during happy hour and been charged more than full price.  The first time I let it go.  The 2nd I noticed on my receipt I'd been charged for an import so I complained.  The guy behind the counter said - oh that one's not on happy hour.  When I pointed to the part of the label where my GB said it was made in SAN JOSE, CA for heaven's sake and it doesn't get much more domestic than that he said "oh that's a micro brew so it costs more."  Well you need a new sign and a dictionary apparently Pizzeria Avellino because Domestic and Import have VERY specific meanings which you are not too familiar with.  There are better places close by to spend my money and so that's what I'll be doing - going ELSEWHERE.
author: Rebekah D.

description:
We are picky about pizza--but THANK GOD Pizza Avellino came along!
This is good pizza in SF, and that is not that easy to find, surprisingly. 

These guys know pizza, they do it well, and it has great crust, great sauce and very easy to call ahead and swing by and pickup for our Friday night Pizza runs! We have also eaten here and the outside tables are nice and being at the edge of the Presidio is also a plus. 

Make this place a part of your routine, its worth it!
author: Krutika P.

description:
This place is great.  If you ask me, what makes a really good pizza is the cheese.  Sauce is one thing, crust is also important, but without good cheese you don't really have pizza.  The cheese here is amazing, just enough gorgonzola to be noticed, but not enough to overpower.  My wife and I really like the rustica style pies, but then again we are from the west coast.  They make enough types of pies that people with a new york bias won't be disappointed.  All are affordable, and slices are available for those who are too timid to get a whole pie.  Seriously, though, if you just get a slice what are you going to eat for breakfast the next morning?

My three boys love both the new york style and the rustica.  The toppings are really good as well.  Outdoor seating will be great for sunny days, and for a place that has only been open a very short while, it is run well.  Again, though I have to mention the pizza rustica, either four-cheese or prosciutto, are worth selling heirloom jewelry for.  Good thing, though, the prices are low enough so that won't come up.
author: Tony M.

description: Very disappointed that they have changed their menu and no longer make rustic pizzas -such as prosciutto, 4 cheeses, and/or greco  which were my favorites. They seem to be heading in the direction of becoming a generic pizza restaurant and it's a shame. i guess I'll just go to A-16 for my pizza.
author: Renzo S.

description: update: beer & wine coming in two weeks.
author: Angela N.

description: This is authentic new york pizza.  I really hope the owner reads this... Don't change the recipe to be west coast style.  People who give this place low marks on pizza just don't know how hard it is to find new york pizza slices and have no clue what new york pizza slices are supposed to be; and these guys have done it.  Good job fellas.
author: Sam T.

description: Amazing thin slice, crunchy crust pizza!  Great service.  Fast.  If ordering a whole pie we usually call it in before heading over.  Nice happy hour price for beers.  Small & cozy pizza joint.  Family friendly.  Our daughter wanted to bring a few friends for her birthday and we called ahead to place the pizza order and they saved a table for us!
author: S R.

description: A welcome addition to the neighborhood. Simple menu that delivers. The NY style pizza was really good. Excellent crust and I can tell they use higher quality ingredients than some places. When they get beer and wine it will be hard to find a better place to go for NY style pizza.
author: Robert O.

description: Definitely a good spot. Our go-to used to be Giorgio's, which is still tasty, but somehow Avellino's thin crust is now the new standard.
author: yvonne l.

description: Finally a pizza by the slice place just outside the Lombard gates! I lived in the Presidio for a few years and the lack of food close by was always an annoyance. The pizza was crispy and perfectly charred on the bottom. My husband and I showed up right at closing time, but they were nice enough to unlock their doors and prepare a slice for us. The mushroom was excellent since it had sauteed mushrooms similar to E'angelos but minus the garlic and butter which would have overpowered the tangy sauce. This place will be even better with some beer on tap and the outdoor seating. I'll miss the french toast at Curbside Too (I've negated the taqueria from memory), but I'm so glad this didn't turn into another overpriced Marina place.
author: Luchen F.

description: 3 stars for the crispy thin crust, 1 star for replacing the taqueria. I got a slice of cheese and thought it could have used more sauce and cheese. Some of the topping combos looked good, but you have to order a whole pie.
author: Laura B.

description: This is an amazing pizzeria. It has an old italian feel. The pizza crust is thin and the pizza has a flavor of its own. It is a great find in a cute neighborhood with very nice employees. Ralph really takes pride in the pies he produces and my family and I can hardly wait to go back. We drove all the way for colma, ca just to try his pizza and we are hooked.
author: Laura W.

description: Came in the other day for a quick bite with a friend after a glorious day at Crissy Field. I loved the Rustic style with proscuitto and fresh arugula. This is as good as any pizza elsewhere in the city. Will definetely be back. Cute place! Salad and beer and wine would make good additions.
author: suzanne m.

description: I finally don't have to cross town to Arinell to get a great slice of pizza.  I'm from NY and an Avellino cheese slice is what I grew up on.  The rustic pizzas are also really good with the pesto giving them a nice flavor kick.  Turns out the pizza chef is from the Bronx and has been making these pies for 30 years.  Let's hope he stays.
author: Susan C.

description: I went here last night and I must say - this is my new favorite pizza place in the city.  They have 2 styles: Napoletena and NY.  I tried them both and they are both delicious.  The Prosciutto Napoletena might just be the best pizza ever made.  Its very similar to Pizzeria da Michele in terms of crust.  For those of you who really know pizza, you know what I'm talking about.
author: A M.

description: I'm a native New Yorker and am NOT a fan of the squishy doughy crust that they use out here at many places.  I also believe that you don't need to drown the thing in cheese, ingredients should be balanced, and the quality of your tomato sauce is important.  I also think that pineapple and ham on a pizza is an abomination... That being said, this place has a solid thin crust pizza.  Not the best in town, but very good.  I ordered an XL Sausage and Mushroom and a Medium Pepperoni and we all agreed that the Pepperoni was better.  The sausage is ok, but Giorgio's uses a better quality sausage, and the mushrooms seemed a little tired and bland. We did the pizza to go and I think that the sheer size of the XL made it a little soggy on the trip home while the medium size retained more crunch.  The pepperoni was spicy and tasty as well.  I too used a coupon but would actually go back and pay full price for their Pepperoni pizza again. I do wish they had more toppings, such as fresh basil.
author: Priscilla C.

description:
this place is amazing. period. 

the guys behind the counter are so nice and welcoming, offering me a slice of  pizza napoletana to try while i paid for my large ny pepperoni pizza to go. i am happy to report each variety was equally delicious. the toppings were so perfectly proportioned, and i felt the love and care that went into it. it is, by far, the best ny pizza in the city. 

i moved to san francisco from brooklyn, where i lived for 5 years, and i ate a slice everyday. it seriously was a taste of home. 

thanks guys. im hooked.
author: Dana C.

description: You have to take your hat off to anyone with the chutzpah to open a restaurant in San Francisco in 2009.  Excellent NY style pizza in a simple place.  Rustic pizzas are pretty darn good also. Wine, beer and salads are coming soon, but it doesn't even matter. This place is all about the slices and pies.
author: butt p.

description: Pizza worth trekking across town for.  Stopped in before a hike in Marin.  I have been looking for a great pizza and location for a long time.  Can't wait to go back soon....maybe they'll have beer by then!
author: R H.

description: Oh man this pizza is good!!!  I had the Prosciutto which is the Italian style and it was amazing.  I wish I had a beer to wash it down but the owners tell me its in the works.  Joel and Steve are the owners and are a great addition to the neighborhood.  Good Luck Gentlemen!  I am a fan.
author: Paul R.
